desc: NOTCH2 encodes a transmembrane receptor that regulates many aspects of development by affecting cell-fate determination.

NOTCH2 encodes an evolutionarily conserved transmembrane receptor that plays a key role in cellular signaling and cell-fate determination through the NOTCH signaling pathway (PMID: 19165418). Four NOTCH receptors (NOTCH1-4) exist in mammals, with NOTCH1 and NOTCH2 genes being the most closely related paralogs (PMID: 26062937). NOTCH2 binds Jagged1/2, and Delta 1, which leads to activation of the NOTCH proteins (PMID: 10221902, 9245493). NOTCH2 is frequently mutated or dysregulated in a variety of cancers, including hepatocellular carcinoma, hematological malignancies, lung adenocarcinoma and gastric cancer (PMID: 27158037). Similar to NOTCH1 mutations, cancer-associated alterations in NOTCH2 signaling can result in both gain- or loss-of-function outcomes. For example, truncating mutations in NOTCH2, known to cause Hajdu-Cheney syndrome, interrupt the regulation of the protein degradation process, resulting in a functional, but constitutively active intracellular domain (PMID: 15284851, 21378989). Conversely, NOTCH2 activating mutations were observed in small cell lung cancer (SCLC) (PMID: 24100291, 26168399). Furthermore, frameshift indels or nonsense mutations in NOTCH2 that truncates the PEST domain of the protein have also been observed in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma associated with hepatitis C virus (PMID: 25381127).
